Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): NgTscPlugin should clean up after program creation
Issues.Body:
`NgTscPlugin` wraps an incoming `ts.CompilerHost` in an `NgCompilerHost`
which patches all `ts.SourceFile`s in the program with referenced shims. In
order to not emit triple-slash `<reference>` directives that refer to shim
files, these patches have to be cleaned up by calling
`NgCompilerHost.postProgramCreationCleanup()` before emit. Previously, the
`NgTscPlugin` was not doing this cleanup.

This commit fixes the bug (which is a one-line change), plus adds a
mechanism in the `NgtscTestEnvironment` to run compilation via the plugin,
allowing for a test to be written.

# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package @angular/forms
Unable to confirm if it is related to other packages.

### Is this a regression?
No, the previous angular 8 version does not present this issue.

### Description

Any instances pertaining the form keeps piling up in memory. Hence, everything else from the form up to its container (component, modal, or anything else) are not being garbage collected. Hence, memory is hugely leaking (See image below of nodes piling up).
A very simple sample demo has been uploaded as an example to represent this issue in its minimum expression. It is a very simple two page app: an auth page with a single input field (template driven form) and the explore page to simplify things up. There are 2 buttons inside the auth page; one of them is the submit button of the form. Both buttons navigate to the explore page. (Is done this way to detect the possible issue). 
The explore page has a button to navigate back to the auth page and close the loop. 

To prove the issue, we navigate back and forth using only the buttons (completely ignoring the input field). 
We just keep routing back and forth pressing the buttons. The result is the expected behaviour where garbage is collected.
This also proves that the issue is unrelated to the router.

Issues.Title: feat(compiler-cli): explain why an expression cannot be used in AOT compilations
Issues.Body: During AOT compilation, the value of some expressions need to be known at compile time. The compiler has to ability to statically evaluate expressions the best it can, but there can be occurrences when an expression cannot be evaluated statically. For instance, the evaluation could depend on a dynamic value or syntax is used that the compiler does not understand. Alternatively, it is possible that an expression could be statically evaluated but the resulting value would be of an incorrect type. In these situations, it would be helpful if the compiler could explain why it is unable to evaluate an expression. To this extend, the static interpreter in Ivy keeps track of a trail of `DynamicValue`s which follow the path of nodes that were considered all the way to the node that causes an expression to be considered dynamic. Up until this commit, this rich trail of information was not surfaced to a developer so the compiler was of little help to explain why static evaluation failed, resulting in situations that are hard to debug and resolve. This commit adds much more insight to the diagnostic that is produced for static evaluation errors. For dynamic values, the trail of `DynamicValue` instances is presented to the user in a meaningful way. If a value is available but not of the correct type, the type of the resolved value is shown. Resolves FW-2155 ---

Issues.Title: Unable to distinguish between different NgZones used on the same page
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

This is really about an API design flaw/limitation, so it falls somewhere between a bug and a feature request. However there is a specific situation in the upgrade package that could arguably be considered a bug.

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package @angular/core.

### Description

`NgZone.isInAngularZone()`, is a static method, which means that it can only answer if we are currently running in any Angular Zone, rather than the one for the "current" application.

Angular has always been designed to support multiple applications running on a single page. While the CLI is not particularly conducive to this situation, that does not change this design intent. 

However, by default, each application will have its own NgZone, and underlying zone. Thus if you have two apps called App1 and App2, they will have different zones, unless you go out of your way to avoid that.

The problem is that you cannot tell which one you are running in. `NgZone.isInAngularZone()` will return true regardless of which of App1 or App2's zone you are running in. Now this is not always a particularly huge deal. That API is only used twice in angular outside the tests or assertions. The first is to print a warning message if navigation is triggered 

However, if used in a pattern like this: `NgZone.isInAngularZone() ? cb() : ngZone.run(cb)`, that is a problem, since the zone we are currently running in could be the one for App2, when the callback needs to run in the zone for App1. If that code seems at all unlikely, it shouldn't, since it came from this repository. It only runs when using `downgradeModule()`, but it is still arguably buggy:

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/d1ea1f4c7f3358b730b0d94e65b00bc28cae279c/packages/upgrade/src/common/src/downgrade_component.ts#L90

I expect a very similar pattern occurs from time to time in third party libraries, or even in application code. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
Ideally there would be an instance method on NgZone that would return true if you are running in that specific zone.

Also, ideally the existing static methods would be deprecated, in favor of new versions named something like `IsInAnyAngularZone`, to indicate that it returns true if you are in any such zone. This would encourage existing users of this api to decide if they they are concerned with running in the zone for a specific app, or if they care about running in any angular zone. For example, some code may simply want to make sure it is running outside of any angular zone for performance or correctness reasons. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered
A different possibility would be to move the zone to the platform level, and force all apps to use the same zone. That would be a big breaking change, with implications on several other apis. It also eliminates the change-detection speedup that comes from each app having their own zone.

Issues.Title: fix(core): don't consider inherited NG_ELEMENT_ID during DI
Issues.Body:
Special DI tokens like `ChangeDetectorRef` and `ElementRef` can provide a factory via `NG_ELEMENT_ID`. The problem is that we were reading it off the token as `token[NG_ELEMENT_ID]` which will go up the prototype chain if it couldn't be found on the current token, resulting in the private `ViewRef` API being exposed, because it extends `ChangeDetectorRef`.

These changes fix the issue by guarding the property access with `hasOwnProperty`.

Fixes #36235.

I had already reported and fixed this for angular 6 (#11833, #11834), and the fix was still working as of angular 8.0. ### Reproduction in git bash, run `ng serve`. Expected: the console output is colored (since the terminal supports that) Actual: the console output doesn't use colors ## üåç Your Environment

... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.901.8
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.901.8

typescript                        3.8.3
webpack                           4.42.0
## Analysis It seems that this regression was introduced by c4313f55e4412dba50a8d09c4daa4a20642b8e77. Specifically, color support checking is now done in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/1cd51e64c7331a9cc48d59e8fd6df74d3c6c48f3/packages/angular/cli/utilities/color.ts#L11-L14 Alas, when node is run within a MINGW terminal (as installed by git for windows), `process.stdout` is a `Socket`, causing `instanceof WriteStream` to return false, and all use of colors by the angular CLI to be disabled, even though the MINGW terminal supports colors just fine ... An easy fix is: ```javascript // Typings do not contain the function call (added in Node.js v9.9.0) export const supportsColor = process.stdout instanceof WriteStream && ((process.stdout as unknown) as { getColorDepth(): number }).getColorDepth() > 1 || process.env.MSYSTEM; // MINGW terminals support color even though nodejs mistakes them for a Socket ``` If desired, I can submit a PR to that effect. Alternatively, you might prefer to delegate to angular_devkit/core/src/terminal/caps.ts instead, whose vendored implementation of `supportsColor` still contains my earlier fix. However, not knowing your policy for dependencies across npm packages I don't feel comfortable submitting a PR to that effect.

Issues.Title: bug(TABS): Ink bar could use transformX instead of left to improve performance.
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open https://stackblitz.com/angular/lnjdedkpgdg (basic example from [Docs](https://material.angular.io/components/tabs/examples))
2. Open Chrome Dev Tools
3. Go to Performance tab
4. Select 6x CPU Slowdown
5. Observe the line animation as you click through the elements.
 
#### Expected Behavior

Performance is optimal for each device. It should worsen somewhat linearly. This is particularly noticeable when using tabs to provide fixed navigation elements on a page (i.e., https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Roboto) that have their active element updated on scroll.

Performance becomes very poor very fast depending on device. I.e., simulated 6x CPU slowdown on a 2019 Macbook Air makes it very noticeable there are frames taking longer than 16ms to render the ink bar animation (meaning the ink bar appears to "jump" instead of animate)

#### Notes

From Paul Irish ca. 2012: "...left has very large time to paint each frame, which results in a choppier transition" (https://www.paulirish.com/2012/why-moving-elements-with-translate-is-better-than-posabs-topleft/)

Affected line: https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/tabs/ink-bar.ts#L95

Issues.Title: refactor: use lightweight token for injecting radio group
Issues.Body:
The Angular Material `MatRadioButton` component currently optionally
injects the `MatRadioGroup`. This causes the `MatRadioGroup` implementation
to be always retained in application bundles.

This is problematic as the use of radio groups is not always required.
i.e. it's valid to use a standalone radio button. In those cases, we do
not want to retain the radio group implementation unnecessarily.

This has always been an issue, but the issue became more significant
in Ivy where component factory and definitions are attached directly
to the `MatRadioGroup` class (resulting in a more significant size increase).

We fix this by using a lightweight token for injecting the parent
radio group optionally. This solves the retention issue if a standalone
radio button is used.

Related to: #19576.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: use lightweight token for injecting radio group" (#19645)

Issues.Title: refactor: use lightweight token for lazy menu content
Issues.Body:
Angular Material supports lazy content for menus. It does this
by querying for the `MatMenuContent` directive in the `MatMenu`
component. This is problematic though as it always causes
`MatMenuContent` to be retained as its used as actual query predicate
token.

To solve this, we use a lightweight injection token for querying
the lazy content (if present). This optimizes applications using
the Angular Material menu without lazy content.

Related to: #19576.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: use lightweight token for lazy menu content" (#19644)

Issues.Title: refactor: use light-weight token for form-field in range-picker input
Issues.Body:
The date range picker could be used outside the `MatFormField`
component in practice. Right now though, the date-picker input
always has a hard-reference on the `MatFormField` component, causing
it to be retained. This would be the same in View Engine, but with
Ivy this signifies a larger size issue as factories/definitions are
directly attached to the component.

To allow for better tree-shaking / optimizations, we use the form-field
light-weight injection token, so that the date range picker can be used
outside of a form-field with minimal cost.

Related to: #19576.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor: use light-weight token for form-field in range-picker input" (#19643)

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): sometimes incorrectly swapping items at the ends of the list
Issues.Body:
The drop list has some logic that doesn't allow a swap to occur if the items being swapped are the same as the ones in the previous swap and the direction of the user's pointer hasn't changed. This is set up so that we don't trigger a swap for every pixel, if the user's pointer lands on a different item after the previous swap is done.

The above-mentioned logic can be problematic if the user takes an item from the middle, drags it out of the list and then inserts it at the end while dragging upwards. In this case the list won't allow the swap, because the item is the same as the one in the previous swap and the pointer's direction hasn't changed.

These changes resolve the issue by preventing the swap only if the user's pointer landed on the same item after the previous swap was finished.

Fixes #19249.

Issues.Title: feat(cdk-experimental/menu): Implement grouping logic for menuitems
Issues.Body:
The MenuBar and Menu pattern allows for MenuItems which have the
menuitemcheckbox or menuitemradio roles. This implements the grouping
logic for, menuitemradio which ensures that sibling items within a
CdkMenu or CdkMenGroup are logically connected and only one can be
checked. It also implements the logic for menuitemcheckbox. Further it
implements the logic for emitting checked events for elements marked
menuitemcheckbox and menuitemradio from their enclosing groups.


-----

Note that I opted not to allow the disabled property on `CdkMenu` and `CdkMenuGroup` since this follows more in line with `mat-menu`, and how I interpreted the pattern. However if we decide to implement this functionality it can be easily added with a followup pr.
